If they don‚Äôt follow them, they could face lawsuits from patients or their families. This is more common in the U.S. than in India. In the U.S., the ‚ÄúMedical Standard of Care‚Äù is set by the governing bodies of each specialty. For example: (1) A General Practioner who is a member of ACP must follow guidelines of ACP. (2) A diabetes doctor must follow the guidelines of the American Diabetes Association (ADA) and (3) An endocrinologist should follow the guidelines established by the American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists (AACE).
* These governing bodies primarily serve the interests of their members, who pay regular membership fees. When new research suggests lowering the threshold for prescribing medication, they are quick to adopt those recommendations. But when new findings suggest a more conservative or less profitable approach, they are often slow
‚Äîor unwilling‚Äîto change. This leads to conflicting guidelines.
In 2018 when ACP issued revised diabetes treatment relaxing them from 6.5 to 8.0 reading for HbA1C there was a huge hue and cry as this would have reduced many practitioners income by 49-60 percent. Within a week AACE reiterated their guidelines of 6.5% to protect income of their members.
This is human nature. Once people become used to higher income, they resist any change that might reduce it. A Hindi couplet written 500 years ago captures this perfectly:
‚ÄúBadhat badhat sampatti salil, man saroj badh jai,
Ghatat ghatat, puni na ghate, varu samul kumbhlaye.‚Äù
Translation:
As one‚Äôs wealth increases, so do his desires‚Äîjust like a lotus in a pond that rises with the water level. When the water recedes, the lotus cannot adjust and withers away.
When your symptoms improve and you ask your doctor if you can stop taking medications, the answer is usually ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù That‚Äôs because your doctor has been taught to believe that chronic conditions are incurable. From his perspective, your symptoms have improved only because of the medication.
As we begin to discuss specific diseases and medications, you will encounter these challenges. Some members have already written to me, saying they plan to ask their doctor about reducing medications. When you do this, please go prepared‚Äîhave your data (your ‚Äúducks‚Äù) lined up.
This is why, in defining the objective of this group, I specifically state:
‚ÄúThe goal is to empower members to get off chronic medications by teaching them an active lifestyle based on a PBWF (Plant-Based Whole-Foods) diet and Intermittent Fasting.‚Äù
Some of you ask me as to how can you convince your doctors to reduce your medicine. This is a very difficult task. Most doctors don‚Äôt have the time to reeducate themselves. Also specially if it means reducing their income level by half or more.

‚Ä¢ In Defense of Doctors ‚Ä¢
Most people live their young adult lives free of chronic diseases (I‚Äôm not referring to infectious diseases here). When you visit a doctor for the first time as an adult‚Äîusually around the age of 45‚Äì50‚Äîand he checks your blood pressure, blood sugar, cholesterol, and other markers, he has no idea about the trajectory of those markers.
For example, if your blood test shows an A1C of 7.8, he doesn‚Äôt know how rapidly that number has been increasing. Is it rising at a rate of 0.1 per month, or just 0.01? In that situation, it is prudent for him to assume the worst-case scenario. So, he prescribes medication. His objectives are twofold:
1. To change the trajectory and prevent the disease from getting worse.
2. To bring the marker into a range recommended by the professional association that governs his specialty.
For instance, if the doctor is a general practitioner and a member of the American College of Physicians (ACP), the guideline is to keep A1C below 8.0. His goal is simply to prevent the progression of diabetes, so a small dose of medication might be sufficient.
If the doctor is a member of the American Diabetes Association (ADA), he aims to bring the A1C below 7.0 and will likely prescribe a higher dose.
If the doctor is an endocrinologist and a member of the American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists (AACE), his target is an A1C below 6.5. He may prescribe two medications.
Most people, after leaving the doctor‚Äôs office and filling the prescription, start taking their medications regularly‚Äîbut only make minor changes to their diet and lifestyle. The most common ones include replacing sugar with artificial sweeteners and switching from regular soft drinks to diet sodas (which, as we will see in later posts, can actually worsen the condition).
Now, if a particular patient‚Äîlike yourself‚Äîis more conscientious and makes significant changes to diet and lifestyle, the numbers may improve dramatically by the time of the next doctor‚Äôs visit. However, when you ask the doctor to stop the medication, he may strongly resist. That‚Äôs because, during his medical training, he was taught that chronic diseases cannot be cured. He firmly believes your improved markers are due solely to the medication.
In my experience working with over 250,000 members, I encounter this situation frequently. Sooner or later, each one of you will face this same dilemma. That‚Äôs why I am raising this issue now‚Äîbefore we begin our in-depth discussion of chronic diseases starting next week. Each of you will need to find your own path and, eventually, have this conversation with your doctor.

‚Ä¢Alternate Medicine:
Is it Only a Placebo Effect?‚Ä¢
Many who share success stories with alternative medicine aren‚Äôt lying or trying to promote an agenda. Some of these stories seem miraculous, turning people into lifelong believers. However, not all such successes are due to the placebo effect. My goal is to explain how various factors can influence our judgment and contribute to the spread of myths. Here are some factors to consider:
1. The human body is a self-healing organism, constantly striving to repair itself. Cells die and regenerate regularly, with cycles ranging from days to months.
2. When we‚Äôre sick, we tend to improve our diet and lifestyle unconsciously, which can aid recovery.
3. Because of these factors, the body usually heals itself. Recovery times vary based on the illness, ranging from weeks to years.
4. In times of illness, we often start by consulting traditional medical professionals. If treatments don‚Äôt work, we may turn to alternative therapies like Homeopathy, Ayurveda, or Acupuncture.
5. Sometimes, recovery coincides with trying alternative treatments, leading us to mistakenly attribute healing to these therapies. In reality, the body may have healed on its own.
6. These perceived successes are then shared as proof of alternative medicine‚Äôs effectiveness, even though the treatment may not have been responsible.
7. Success stories get more attention than failures, which are rarely published. This creates a bias, as we are more likely to hear about positive outcomes, further spreading the idea that alternative therapies work when conventional medicine doesn‚Äôt.
If you‚Äôre reading this, you‚Äôre likely a health-conscious individual. Keep these points in mind when you hear about miraculous recoveries. For more insight, check out the documentaries *What The Health* and *Death by Medicine*.

‚Ä¢SIDE EFFECTS and ADRS, OF DRUGS‚Ä¢
Most of us are aware of the concept of drug side effects, which can be either negative or positive. The goal of any drug manufacturer is to minimize negative side effects. If side effects are severe, a drug is unlikely to receive approval from regulatory authorities. Additionally, most side effects are evaluated over short time frames; therefore, effects that only become apparent after prolonged use‚Äîsuch as over decades‚Äîmay go undetected. Drug manufacturers often aim to minimize the disclosure of side effects, revealing only those they cannot conceal or are legally required to disclose.
It‚Äôs important to recognize that all individuals are epigenetically different, so just as specific foods affect us in varied ways, specific drugs also have different effects on each person. This variability makes it difficult to identify all side effects during drug trials. It is not unreasonable to assume that there are certain side effects that your doctor may not be aware of. For example, it has long been known that many diabetic medications can increase the risk of heart disease. However, manufacturers of these medications are only required to demonstrate that their drugs lower blood glucose levels, not that they do not increase the risk of heart disease.
I personally had to stop using Avandia after discovering its potential risks, and I switched to Actos, only to stop that as well for the same reason. This led me to change my diet and lifestyle.
If you are a diabetic, your doctor may be so concerned about your risk of heart disease that they recommend you take statins as a preventive measure. Interestingly, the reverse is also true: if you are a heart patient taking certain drugs, your likelihood of developing diabetes significantly increases.
Understanding Side Effects and Adverse Drug Reactions (ADRs)
The distinction between side effects and adverse drug reactions (ADRs) is often misunderstood. A side effect refers to unintended effects of a drug that occur within the therapeutic range, usually an undesirable secondary effect in addition to the desired therapeutic outcome. Side effects can vary among individuals.
An adverse drug reaction (ADR) is defined as ‚Äúa response to a medicinal product that is noxious and unintended.‚Äù It is estimated that between 3% and 7% of all hospitalizations are due to ADRs, which can occur at normal therapeutic doses. In contrast, drug overdoses represent a different issue entirely.
The leading cause of ADRs is multiple drug interactions. It is crucial for individuals taking several medications to check for potential adverse interactions. The situation becomes even more complex as individuals can respond differently to each drug. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in the U.S. maintains a database of ADRs, which healthcare providers are required to report and is publicly accessible. Medscape also offers a drug interaction checker that can be useful. Of course, discontinuing medications altogether would eliminate this concern.

‚Ä¢NNT & NNH OF DRUGS‚Ä¢
Having explained the concepts of side effects and ADRs, let‚Äôs discuss how various drugs are evaluated in terms of their performance. Two critical criteria in drug evaluation are Number Needed to Treat (NNT) and Number Needed to Heal (NNH).
Number Needed to Treat (NNT)¬†refers to the number of patients a doctor or researcher needs to treat to prevent one additional adverse outcome, such as death. For instance, if a cancer drug reduces the mortality rate from 30% to 25%, the NNT is calculated as 1 divided by the reduction in mortality rate (0.30 - 0.25), resulting in an NNT of 20.
Number Needed to Harm (NNH)¬†refers to the number of patients who need to be treated for one to experience a harmful side effect. For many drugs, the NNH is often lower than the NNT. For example, for statin drugs, the NNH for muscle pain is 21, meaning one in every 21 patients may experience muscle pain.
A tutorial video linked below will help clarify the concepts of NNT and NNH, as well as illustrate how drug companies may legally misrepresent the benefits of their products through statistical jargon.
To illustrate, consider statin drugs. According to The NNT Group, the NNT for statins prescribed for five years to prevent heart disease in individuals without prior heart issues is 104. This means 104 people must take statins for five years to prevent one additional heart attack. Meanwhile, the NNH of 21 indicates that five out of those 104 patients will likely experience muscle loss.
It is alarming to note that when all causes of death from ADRs, adverse drug events (ADEs), medical procedures, and diagnostics are considered, medical care itself becomes a leading cause of death in America, surpassing heart disease and cancer.

‚Ä¢BIAS IN MEDICAL & NUTRITIONAL RESEARCH‚Ä¢
We often assume that conclusions about foods and medications from research studies are honest and accurate. Historically, most nutrition research was government-funded, with key organizations like the NIH in the U.S. and NIN in India. However, budget cuts in the 21st century have led to private industries, particularly food and Pharma, filling the funding gap. Medical and nutritional research can be categorized as follows:
(1) Primary Research
Traditionally funded by the NIH, it focuses on broad public benefits like laboratory studies and randomized trials. Projects like the Human Genome and Human Proteome are still NIH-funded. However, a decrease in government funding has made this research less common.
(2) Applied Research
Applied research uses science to prevent and treat diseases. While some still receive NIH funding, much is now backed by pharma, food, and the supplement industries. It can be divided into research supporting various foods, justifying supplements, or showing harm in certain foods or lifestyles.
(3) Public Health Research
This aims to improve public health at a population level, ideally government-funded, though private industries are increasingly stepping in.
(4) Clinical research
Focused on testing medications, this research is primarily funded by pharmaceutical companies. Variability in how people respond to treatments (e.g., due to gut microbiomes) complicates results. For instance, if a drug helps 30% of participants in a placebo group and 70% in an experimental group, it‚Äôs deemed effective, leading to its prescription for all, even though 60% who either were not cured or cured only due to placebo effect, are still exposed to side effects without gaining any benefit.
(5) Pharmacological Research
This field explores how chemicals interact with biological systems, playing a central role in pharmaceutical development. Some key points worth noting are:
5.1 The goal is not necessarily to cure diseases, as doing so could conflict with the long-term profitability of pharmaceutical companies.
5.2 Pharmaceutical companies often focus on managing health markers such as blood pressure, blood sugar, or cholesterol, which usually require increasing dosages over time.
5.3 These companies emphasize early detection, claiming it saves lives. While this is true for certain conditions like cancer, for most lifestyle diseases, it often leads to starting medication earlier. Additionally, they lobby to lower the thresholds for starting treatment, as seen with medications for blood pressure, blood sugar, and cholesterol.
5.4 Pharmaceutical companies promote tighter control of these markers, often suggesting higher or more frequent dosages. For example, increasing the dosage from two to three pills a day represents a 50% increase in business. This approach influenced the ACCORD study (2001-2009). However, the study backfired, as it showed increased mortality rates in the experimental group, leading to its early termination.
Bias in Research
When we read research papers, we expect them to be honest and objective. However, various factors can distort this objectivity. Numerous studies have shown how research can be manipulated to favor the organization funding it. Some of these biases are summarized below.
(1) Funding Bias
In the U.S., government funding for research has significantly declined over the past five decades. By 2021, private sources contributed $633 billion to research and development (R&D), while government funding amounted to just $76 billion. Private funding often comes with specific interests or conditions, and studies show that research funded by private sources rarely contradicts the interests of the sponsor. This can happen for several reasons:
- Research may be designed to avoid negative outcomes. For example, using the Standard American Diet (SAD) as a control can make almost any alternative diet seem healthier by comparison.
- In some cases, research design can obscure significant negative outcomes. For instance, one study asked college students to consume large amounts of white bread, and their health appeared to improve. However, concluding that white bread is healthy would be misleading, as the students had to reduce their intake of more harmful foods like eggs, sausages, and bacon.
-Funders may cancel research midway if they realize the results will not favor them. To prevent this, a law was enacted requiring that research be registered with government authorities before it begins, ensuring it cannot be canceled midstream. However, this law is not always strictly enforced by bureaucrats who are hoping for a cozy consulting career upon retirement.
- Before any research is published, a synopsis must be provided. Funders often manipulate this summary to downplay negative findings. A notable example is when Senator Bob Dole altered the language of George McGovern's 1977 dietary guidelines. Originally recommending reduced meat consumption, the guidelines were changed to encourage the consumption of lean meat. The two statements have entirely different implications.
(2) Myth Bias
Myths can skew researchers' judgment. For example, high protein intake was long recommended, despite evidence that excessive protein harms kidneys and liver. Similarly, the myth that plant protein is incomplete has been debunked, yet it persisted for years.
The dairy industry perpetuated the idea that milk is the best calcium source, even when evidence suggested it could contribute to osteoporosis.
(3) Scholarly Pride Bias
Respected experts may distort findings to defend earlier positions. An example is Dr. Ancel Keys, whose *Seven Countries Study* promoted low-fat diets by excluding data from 15 countries that contradicted his hypothesis.
(4) Publication Bias
Positive outcomes are more likely to be published, skewing perceptions. Negative results often face reluctance in publication, leading to a distorted understanding of certain therapies.
For example, if three studies find that egg white therapy cures second-stage breast cancer, all three studies will likely get published. However, if seven subsequent studies show it does not, only one or two may be published. Future researchers may then mistakenly conclude the therapy is effective, leading to further studies based on flawed premises.
(5) Media Bias
Media prefers sensational stories, which can lead to biased reporting. The food and pharma industries, significant advertisers, influence the coverage, leading to overexposure of certain diet trends while scientifically sound approaches are underreported. For example, Dr. Atkins' high-protein, high-fat diet received more media coverage than Pritikin‚Äôs low-fat, high-carb approach, despite the latter being scientifically sounder. Sensational books like *Grain Brain* and *Wheat Belly* also received more coverage, influenced by powerful Food industry lobbies that support such narratives. Additionally, since the media relies heavily on advertising revenue from the food and pharmaceutical industries, they often hesitate to publish studies critical of these sectors.
(6) Government Bias
Government agencies often face conflicts of interest, as bureaucrats seek consulting jobs post-retirement, and elected officials raise funds from industries they regulate.
The public relies on Government agencies like the Food & Drug Administration (FDA) to ensure that medical devices are safe.
There is an inherent conflict of interest within the drug and device approval process, as the FDA primarily depends on clinical trials conducted by the very companies that manufacture these products. Research findings are often ambiguous and open to debate. The FDA has, at times, approved drugs and devices despite objections from its own staff. This recently came to light on a device called MitraClip made by Abbott Labs to fix leaky heart valves that was approved by the FDA in 2013. Over 17,000 reports have been filed complaining about this device.
(7) Other Conflicts of Interest
Political, personal ambitions, and other conflicts can further complicate the research landscape.
Conclusion
It‚Äôs crucial to approach research with caution. Understanding potential biases, especially the source of funding, helps reveal the full story behind the findings. Always scrutinize before accepting conclusions.

We‚Äôve discussed how wealthy industries like Food, Pharma, and Health Care influence the information we receive. Now, let‚Äôs examine the roles of Government and Media. By ‚Äúgovernment,‚Äù I mean both elected politicians and bureaucrats.
Politicians need funding to win elections every 4-5 years, and that money often comes from wealthy industries, so it‚Äôs natural for them to support industry interests. Lobbyists work closely with politicians‚Äô staff to ensure this support is secured.
Meanwhile, bureaucrats often seek well-paid positions post-retirement, and there are plenty of opportunities within the food and pharma industries to accommodate them. Consequently, many senior officials are willing to accommodate lobbyists‚Äô requests. All they need is some science to justify their actions, which researchers‚Äîoften industry-funded‚Äîreadily provide.
Let‚Äôs now consider educational institutions, where much of the research is conducted. Imagine you are applying for a Ph.D. program at a leading U.S. university and need financial assistance. This assistance might come from, say, a soft drink manufacturer eager to fund research showing that consuming sugary sodas in moderation can be part of a balanced diet. The company provides funding annually. By the end of the first year, if your research findings are negative, the project might be canceled, and funding cut. This situation encourages researchers to use careful language in reports and potentially manipulate data to achieve favorable outcomes.
The data isn‚Äôt falsified, but choosing specific words or omitting data can still lead to misleading conclusions. Once published in a medical journal, the research paper includes an abstract. Doctors often only read the abstract, so lobbyists work hard to influence the language used here. Professor J. P. Rivers of the Department of Human Nutrition, London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, observed:
‚ÄúThe dispassionate objectivity of scientists is a myth. No scientist is simply involved in the single-minded pursuit of truth; they are also engaged in the passionate pursuit of research grants and professional success.‚Äù
Role of Media
Now, let‚Äôs talk about the role of media and medical journals. Editors have various options for each issue and can select whichever articles they prefer.
Most published media rely on advertising revenue for their income. The proceeds from magazine sales alone don‚Äôt even cover the cost of publication. The largest advertisers are often the big food and pharmaceutical industries. Therefore, it is natural for publishers to avoid controversial content that might jeopardize their relationships with advertisers.
Another factor to consider is article reprints. For example, if you like an article in a magazine like¬†TIME, you can purchase reprints for about $3‚Äì5 each. The cover page shows the magazine cover, but inside, only the article you requested is included.
Imagine you‚Äôre an editor, deciding which health articles to include in the next issue. A dairy industry lobbyist approaches you and suggests that if you publish an article supporting the health benefits of butter, he‚Äôll order half a million reprints to distribute to doctors across the U.S. What would you choose as the editor? That order could bring in nearly a million dollars in extra revenue for the magazine, and if your compensation includes profit-sharing, it could result in a substantial bonus for you.
It‚Äôs important to understand that this scenario isn‚Äôt a conspiracy. No laws are broken, and there‚Äôs no bribery involved. However, the consumer ends up misled, and situations like this happen every day. Posted below as an example is the issue of¬†TIME¬†magazine zone I‚Äôm referring to.üëá

‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ EARLY DETECTION VS PREVENTION ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Another area of concern is the strong emphasis in modern medicine‚Äîand especially on social media‚Äîon early detection of disease. We are constantly told to go for regular screenings to catch conditions like cancer early. Self-monitoring is also heavily promoted.
But here‚Äôs the irony: while early detection gets all the attention, prevention gets almost none. This is especially unfortunate because most lifestyle diseases‚Äîsuch as diabetes, heart disease, obesity, and some cancers‚Äîare entirely preventable through diet and lifestyle modifications. Yet, articles and campaigns promoting such prevention are rare.
Why? Because there is no money in prevention. It threatens the profits of:
- the processed food and animal agriculture industries,
- healthcare providers who benefit from treating chronic disease,
- and the pharmaceutical industry that sells lifelong medications.
Early detection, on the surface, sounds like a good idea. But it implicitly accepts disease as inevitable. The far better approach is to prevent disease from arising in the first place. Unfortunately, if everyone started living healthier lives, many industries‚Äîprocessed food, animal products, hospitals, and drug companies‚Äîwould take a financial hit.
To be clear, this doesn‚Äôt mean there‚Äôs an organized conspiracy. But it does raise an important question: Why is prevention being ignored?
Some leaders in the medical field have spoken out. Dr. Neal Barnard, for instance, founded the organization ‚ÄúDoctors Against Irresponsible Medicine‚Äù, which promotes prevention through lifestyle medicine. The American Board of Internal Medicine has also launched a campaign called ‚ÄúChoosing Wisely‚Äù, encouraging patients and doctors to question unnecessary treatments and focus on evidence-based practices.
Consumers need to be aware of this built-in bias. The system heavily favors early detection over prevention, not because it‚Äôs better for patients, but because it‚Äôs better for business.
It‚Äôs time we shift our focus from managing disease to eliminating its causes. True health comes not from pills or early tests, but from the daily choices we make around food, movement, and lifestyle.

UNNECESSARY TESTS
I previously discussed that what is ‚Äúnormal‚Äù for one group of people may not be the same for another‚Äîespecially when comparing non-vegetarians and vegans. For example, prescribing medication or supplements to a vegan simply because a blood parameter falls outside the normal range can be misguided. It‚Äôs essential to consider other factors in such cases.
Similarly, advising people to undergo numerous tests without cause is not prudent. Tests should be conducted only when there is reason to suspect something may be wrong and when a patient has reported symptoms.
This issue has been debated in the United States for some time. As a result of this debate a foundation was created by the American Board of Internal Medicine (ABIM) with the primary purpose of improving public health. The mission statement on their website is:
‚ÄúTo advance the core values of medical professionalism as a force to improve the quality of health care.‚Äù
Programs supporting this work include the
*Choosing Wisely¬ÆÔ∏è campaign,
*‚ÄúTeaching Value and Choosing Wisely Challenge‚Äù,
* ¬†‚ÄúPutting Stewardship into Medical Education and Training‚Äù grant program.
Of these, ‚ÄúChoosing Wisely‚Äù is of special interest to us. The goal of this campaign is to¬†promote conversations between clinicians and patients by helping patients choose care that is:
* Supported by evidence
* Not duplicative of other tests or procedures already received
* Free from harm
* Truly necessary
It calls upon leading medical specialty societies and other organizations to identify tests or procedures commonly used in their field whose necessity should be questioned and discussed with patients. Doctors are often criticized for prescribing unneeded tests and procedures that harm more than they help and add to medical costs that could otherwise be avoided.
Since the campaign was launched in 2012, more than 400 tests and procedures have been called into question by 70 medical specialty societies with more than half a million member doctors. ‚ÄúMillions of Americans are increasingly realizing that when it comes to health care, more is not necessarily better,‚Äù said Dr. Christine Cassel, president of the ABIM Foundation. ‚ÄúThrough these lists of tests and procedures, we hope to encourage conversations between physicians and patients about what care they truly need.‚Äù
Twelve¬†medical tests and procedures are now being questioned worldwide as unnecessary and potentially cause some harmful results to patients are listed below.
12 Medical Tests to Avoid
1. Avoid Inducing Labor or having a C-Section Before 39 Weeks:
Deliveries before 39 weeks are associated with increased risks of learning disabilities, respiratory issues, and other complications. While early delivery is sometimes necessary, the recommendation is clear: a mature fetal lung test alone, without other medical reasons, is not enough to justify delivery before 39 weeks.
(American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologist; American Academy of Family Physicians)
2. Avoid Routine Annual Pap Tests:
For women at average risk, annual Pap tests (cervical cytology screenings) do not offer added benefits over less frequent screening. (American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists)
3. Avoid CT Scans To Evaluate Minor Head Injuries:
About half of children who visit emergency departments for head injuries receive a CT scan, exposing them to radiation that can increase future cancer risk. These scans involve radiation levels approximately 100 times that of a standard chest X-ray. Observation should precede any decision about CT scanning. (American Academy of Pediatrics)
4. Avoid Stress Tests Using Echocardiographic Images:
For asymptomatic individuals, stress echocardiography adds limited value in assessing cardiovascular risk and may not justify its use. (American Society of Echocardiography)
5. Avoid Prescribing Type 2 Diabetes Medication To Achieve Tight Glycemic Control:
For older adults with Type 2 diabetes, there is no evidence that strict blood sugar control improves health outcomes. In fact, it may lead to higher mortality rates. (American Geriatrics Society)
6. Avoid EEGs (electroencephalography) on Patients With Recurrent Headaches:
Recurrent headaches affect up to 20% of people. However, EEGs provide no diagnostic advantage over a clinical evaluation, do not improve treatment outcomes, and add unnecessary costs. (American Academy of Neurology)
7. Avoid Routinely Treating Acid Reflux:
Anti-reflux medications, while common for adults with GERD, are not effective for reducing symptoms in infants and may even cause harm in certain cases. (Society of Hospital Medicine)
8. Avoid Lipid Profile Tests:
The lipid profile test checks cholesterol and triglyceride levels.
Several scientific papers have proven that people with high so-called ‚Äúbad‚Äù LDL cholesterol live the longest and there is now a large number of findings that contradict the lipid hypothesis that cholesterol has to be lowered at all.
9. Avoid Mammograms:
Mammograms and breast screening have had no impact on breast cancer deaths and have actually been found to increase breast cancer mortality. With toxic radiation, mammogram testing compresses sensitive breast tissue causing pain and possible tissue damage. To make matters worse, the false negative and false positive rates of mammography are a troubling 30% and 89% respectively. Another concern is that many breast cancers occur below the armpits; however, mammography completely misses this auxiliary region, viewing only the breast tissue compressed between two plates of glass. Considering these drawbacks, breast thermography should be given closer consideration. Thermography is a non-invasive and non-toxic technique which can detect abnormalities before the ons no et of a malignancy, and as early as ten years before being recognized by mammography. This makes it much safer and potentially life-saving health test for women who are unknowingly developing abnormalities, as it can take several years for a cancerous tumor to develop and be detected by a mammogram.
10. Avoid PSA Testing:
A PSA blood test looks for prostate-specific antigen, a protein produced by the prostate gland. High levels are supposedly associated with prostate cancer. The problem is that the association isn‚Äôt always correct, and when it is, the prostate cancer isn‚Äôt necessarily deadly. Nearly 20 percent of men will be diagnosed with prostate cancer, which sounds scary, but only about 3 percent of all men die from it. The PSA test usually leads to overdiagnosis ‚Äî biopsies and treatment in which the side effects are impotence and incontinence. Moreover, there is some evidence which suggests that biopsies and treatment actually aggravate prostate cancer. During a needle biopsy, a tumor may need to be punctured several times to retrieve an amount of tissue that‚Äôs adequate enough to be screened. It is believed that this repeated penetration may spread cancer cells into the track formed by the needle, or by spilling cancerous cells directly into the bloodstream or lympathic system.
11. Avoid Routine Colorectal Cancer Screening:
Colorectal cancer screening often results in unnecessary removal of benign polyps which are of no threat to patients and the risks of their treatment or removal far exceed any benefit. The evidence is insufficient to assess the benefits and harms of computed tomographic colonography and fecal DNA testing as screening modalities for colorectal cancer.
12. Avoid Dual Energy X-Ray Absorptiometry (DEXA or DXA):
This technique developed in the 1980s that measures, among many things, bone mineral density. The scans can determine bone strength and signs of osteopenia, a possible precursor to osteoporosis. Limitations abound, though. Measurements vary from scan to scan of the same person, as well as from machine to machine. DEXA doesn‚Äôt capture the collagen-to-mineral ratio, which is more predictive of bone strength than just mineral density. And higher bone mineral density doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean stronger bones, for someone with more bone mass will have more minerals but could have weaker bones.
The ABIM initiative to reduce unnecessary testing is commendable, though it has received limited media coverage. Ideally, information on these recommendations would be displayed in clinic waiting rooms for patients to see.
I encourage everyone to understand these recommendations and make informed decisions. While these tests may still be needed in certain situations, it is wise to discuss your options with your doctor or consider a second opinion before proceeding.

‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢    MY STORY   ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Today, I‚Äôd like to share a personal story of how I became interested in healthy eating and lifestyle, the sources of information I rely on, and my approach to research.
Like many people, I used to believe that my diet and lifestyle were healthy and that my chronic illnesses were largely due to genetics. My dad and his brothers all had heart issues, hypertension, and diabetes. Two of them passed away from heart attacks in their 40s and 50s. I didn‚Äôt smoke, and my alcohol intake was limited to a few margaritas on weekends. We were mostly vegetarian, only having meat or seafood when eating out or at gatherings. I drank a lot of milk and loved eggs, convinced they were good for me. My morning and evening tea was made mostly of milk, which I took pride in. In the summer, I enjoyed cold coffee, mango milkshakes, and Rooh Afza lassi. Most mornings, I had either fried eggs or avocado masala omelettes with parathas.
After graduating from IITK in 1971, my BMI was 22.7. I was a weightlifter and bodybuilder, even winning third-place prizes in these categories. However, over the years, my BMI gradually increased to 30.4 by the age 62. At 47, I started medication for gout. Avandia, another diabetes medication, was added which was later replaced with Actos due to cardiac risks. Later, Actos was banned for similar reasons. At 54, I started thyroid medication, and by 58, I was diagnosed with sleep apnea and advised to use a CPAP machine due to loud snoring. My snoring was so loud that nobody could share a room with me at night and my wife had to use ear plugs.
Our meals were largely vegetarian but high in ghee. Growing up, our meals were divided into ‚ÄúKachcha Khana‚Äù and ‚ÄúPakka Khana.‚Äù Lunch typically consisted of daal, roti, subji, curd, and rice, while dinner included parathis, curried potatoes, other vegetables, and curd. WHY WHOLE FOOD?
Lack of Fiber Question
The lack of fiber in refined sugar causes it to be absorbed rapidly in the intestines, overwhelming the liver. The liver converts the fructose portion into fat, leading to fatty liver (NAFLD), visceral fat, and insulin resistance by interfering with insulin signaling in muscle cells.
To explain this concept visually, I often show a short clip from Lucy in the Chocolate Factory (watch here).
https://youtu.be/AnHiAWlrYQc?si=sMCMxEmYv-AvU-un
In the video, when chocolates arrive at a comfortable pace, Lucy wraps them neatly and sends them down the conveyor belt to the shipping department ‚Äî everything works smoothly. But when the belt speeds up, chaos ensues: the chocolates end up in the wrong places ‚Äî her mouth, her hat, and even her blouse!
Our liver works in much the same way. When sugar enters the bloodstream slowly (as it does when we eat whole fruits, which contain fiber), the liver can manage it efficiently. But when sugar arrives too quickly ‚Äî as in fruit juice or processed sweets ‚Äî the liver becomes overwhelmed. Instead of packaging fructose into fat for safe storage in subcutaneous fat cells (under the skin), it diverts it to unhealthy destinations: liver fat, visceral fat, and intramyocellular fat (inside muscle cells). These misplaced fats cause a cascade of problems, including NAFLD, insulin resistance, and type 2 diabetes.
All this can happen simply because someone chose apple juice instead of an apple.
The Question
This raises an intriguing question:
If refined sugar (devoid of fiber) can cause such damage, what about refined fats (like oils) and refined proteins (like meat, dairy, and eggs) ‚Äî which are also devoid of fiber?
The Answer
Let‚Äôs unpack this carefully.
When we examine refined fats and refined proteins, the mechanisms differ from refined sugar ‚Äî but the metabolic consequences are surprisingly similar. When these nutrients are consumed without the natural fiber, phytonutrients, and water found in whole plant foods, they too overload our metabolic systems.
1. Refined Fats (Oils, Ghee, Butter, etc.)
Refined fats are essentially pure triglycerides extracted from whole foods like nuts, seeds, or olives ‚Äî stripped of fiber, antioxidants, and other protective compounds.
Key consequences:
‚Ä¢¬†¬†¬†Rapid absorption and extreme calorie density:
Oils are absorbed almost instantly and are the most calorie-dense foods on Earth (9 kcal/g). Even small amounts can create a large caloric surplus, promoting weight gain and visceral fat accumulation.
‚Ä¢¬†¬†¬†Fat accumulation in liver and muscle:
Excess dietary fat ‚Äî especially saturated and omega-6‚Äìrich oils ‚Äî infiltrates liver (hepatocytes) and muscle cells (myocytes), leading to hepatic steatosis (fatty liver) and lipotoxicity.
‚Ä¢¬†¬†¬†Insulin resistance:
Intracellular fat disrupts insulin signaling, reducing glucose uptake and increasing blood sugar and insulin levels ‚Äî the same end result seen with sugar overload.
‚Ä¢¬†¬†¬†Inflammation:
Many refined oils (corn, sunflower, safflower, etc.) are rich in omega-6 fatty acids, which promote inflammatory compounds that worsen insulin resistance and damage blood vessels.
So yes ‚Äî refined fats can indeed lead to fatty liver, visceral obesity, and insulin resistance, just through fat overload instead of fructose overload.
2. Refined Proteins (Meat, Eggs, Dairy)
Though not ‚Äúrefined‚Äù in the industrial sense, animal-based foods are naturally devoid of fiber and phytonutrients, and often high in saturated fat and amino acids (like methionine and leucine) that alter metabolic pathways.
Key consequences:
‚Ä¢¬†¬†¬†Lack of fiber:
Without fiber, there‚Äôs no buffering of nutrient absorption, no support for gut microbes, and no binding of bile acids. This increases the metabolic burden on the liver and kidneys and promotes gut dysbiosis.
‚Ä¢¬†¬†¬†Fatty liver and insulin resistance:
Animal proteins often come packaged with saturated fat, contributing directly to hepatic fat accumulation. High intake of certain amino acids (especially branched-chain amino acids) activates the mTOR pathway, which interferes with insulin signaling and promotes insulin resistance.
‚Ä¢¬†¬†¬†Increased visceral fat:
Chronic insulin resistance caused by animal-based diets drives hyperinsulinemia, which promotes fat storage, particularly around abdominal organs.
Epidemiological studies consistently link high consumption of red and processed meats with NAFLD, type 2 diabetes, and metabolic syndrome.
3. The Unifying Concept: Fiber and Nutrient Synergy
Fiber is not just a bulking agent ‚Äî it‚Äôs a metabolic protector.
It:
‚Ä¢¬†¬†¬†Slows absorption of glucose, fats, and amino acids, preventing overload.
‚Ä¢¬†¬†¬†Feeds gut bacteria, which produce short-chain fatty acids (like butyrate) that improve insulin sensitivity and protect the liver.
‚Ä¢¬†¬†¬†Binds bile acids and fats, reducing lipid absorption and cholesterol levels.
When fiber is missing ‚Äî whether from refined sugar, refined fat, or animal protein ‚Äî metabolic overload follows. The result is lipid accumulation, oxidative stress, inflammation, and ultimately insulin resistance.
In essence, fiber and phytonutrient synergy is nature‚Äôs way of ensuring that the body receives nutrients at a pace it can handle ‚Äî just like Lucy wrapping chocolates at a steady, manageable speed. Remove the fiber, and metabolic chaos begins.

WHY WHOLE FOOD?
Additional Perspectives
When we try to understand something that isn‚Äôt yet clear to us, it helps to view it from multiple perspectives. My post yesterday on ‚ÄúWhy Whole Food‚Äù focused on how the presence of fiber slows the absorption of food in the small intestine, preventing many lifestyle diseases. Today, let‚Äôs explore a few other perspectives.
(1) Time Available for Food Absorption
Another important factor is the amount of time food remains in the small intestine for absorption.
Whole, fiber-rich foods move through the intestines more quickly, allowing less time for absorption. This has two important consequences:
* Reduced calorie absorption: Fewer calories are absorbed into the body, helping maintain a healthy weight.
* Enhanced gut health: More undigested food reaches the colon, providing nourishment for beneficial gut bacteria. These microbes flourish and, in turn, produce essential nutrients such as vitamins and short-chain fatty acids that strengthen immunity and overall health.
A good example of this is resistant starch found in beans. Because it resists absorption in the small intestine, it leads to a lower glycemic spike during the meal itself ‚Äî less glucose enters the bloodstream since less starch is absorbed. In addition, when this resistant starch reaches the colon, it feeds beneficial bacteria that further improve metabolic health, a phenomenon known as the second meal effect.
Leaky Gut Syndrome
When food is refined and stripped of fiber, it moves slowly through the intestines, allowing nearly all calories to be absorbed before reaching the colon. This leaves the gut bacteria starved. In response, they begin consuming the mucin layer that protects the intestinal lining, eventually damaging the epithelial barrier ‚Äî a condition known as leaky gut.
Leaky gut allows harmful substances to enter the bloodstream and is believed to be a root cause of many autoimmune diseases. Over 80 such conditions have been identified, including hypothyroidism, arthritis, and lupus ‚Äî and the number continues to rise.
(2) The Protective Skin of Plants
The outer skin of plant foods not only protects the plant itself but is also rich in phytochemicals and antioxidants that nourish our gut microbiome. When we consume refined foods that lack these protective layers, our gut microbes are deprived of vital nutrients ‚Äî and consequently, our bodies are deprived of the many beneficial compounds those microbes produce.
It is estimated that our microbiome may generate up to half of the chemicals required for human health ‚Äî a staggering reminder of how deeply we depend on these microbial partners.
A Note of Humility
Many senior nutrition scientists agree that our understanding of nutrition is still in its infancy ‚Äî there is far more we don‚Äôt know than what we do. Recognizing this, we should act with humility and choose what nature has already perfected over millions of years: whole foods.
Forming the habit of eating whole, unprocessed foods is not difficult, especially when begun early in life. The habits children form when young often last a lifetime ‚Äî and choosing whole foods is one of the most powerful habits we can pass on to the next generation.

‚Ä¢Healthy vs Unhealthy ‚Ä¢
A common question that keeps coming up is: ‚ÄúIs this food healthy?‚Äù
We also frequently encounter media articles comparing one food with another, making claims such as:
1.	Jaggery is healthy
2.	Red Wine is healthy
3.	Olive Oil is healthy
These comparisons often confuse people because they blur the crucial difference between something being healthy and something being healthier.
Let‚Äôs get this straight:
Just because one food is less harmful than another doesn‚Äôt automatically make it healthy. Being ‚Äúhealthier‚Äù is a relative concept‚Äîit only means it‚Äôs the lesser evil when compared to something worse. That doesn‚Äôt qualify it as beneficial or safe for regular consumption. Let‚Äôs look at the three examples mentioned above:
1. Jaggery vs Refined Sugar
Jaggery is often marketed as a traditional, ‚Äúnatural‚Äù sweetener with supposed health benefits. Articles tout it as rich in minerals like iron and magnesium. But here‚Äôs the catch‚Äîthey‚Äôre always comparing it to refined white sugar.
Sure, if your only two options are jaggery and refined sugar, jaggery is the slightly better choice. But that does not mean it is healthy. It‚Äôs still a concentrated form of sugar and will still spike your blood glucose, burden your liver, and contribute to insulin resistance.
If you‚Äôve already managed to eliminate added sugars from your diet and are getting all the sugar you need from fruits and vegetables, please don‚Äôt go back and ‚Äúreward‚Äù yourself by adding jaggery. That would be a step backward, not forward.
Want something truly better? Eat sugarcane. It has fiber, water, and micronutrients. Much less damaging than jaggery‚Äîwhich is, in essence, boiled-down, dehydrated sugarcane juice minus all the good stuff.
2. Red Wine vs Other Alcohols
Red wine often gets glowing coverage in lifestyle magazines and health columns. The reason? It contains resveratrol, a plant compound with antioxidant properties that has shown some promise in lab studies.
But let‚Äôs be clear: that doesn‚Äôt make red wine a health food. It is still alcohol, a known toxin that damages the liver, increases cancer risk, and impairs brain function over time.
So why the good press? It‚Äôs all about context. The studies compare red wine to other alcoholic beverages. So, in that narrow context, red wine emerges as the least harmful. If you are absolutely forced to choose between red wine, white wine, and scotch (say, you‚Äôre kidnapped and only these three are on offer‚Äîno water, no tea, no coconut water), go with red wine. At least it brings along a few antioxidants for the ride.
But if you don‚Äôt already drink alcohol, please don‚Äôt start‚Äînot for the resveratrol, not for ‚Äúheart health,‚Äù not for social status. Even the World Health Organization is crystal clear on this: no level of alcohol consumption is completely safe.
Want resveratrol? Eat a handful of red grapes. Or better still, eat a bowl of berries, which are even richer in health-protective phytonutrients‚Äîwithout the alcohol, of course.
3. Olive Oil vs Other Oils
Many health-conscious Indians have now adopted extra virgin olive oil, believing it‚Äôs a ‚Äúhealthy fat.‚Äù The marketing works beautifully: words like ‚Äúcold-pressed,‚Äù ‚Äúextra virgin,‚Äù and even ‚ÄúMediterranean diet‚Äù all paint olive oil as a miracle elixir.
But here‚Äôs the inconvenient truth: Olive oil is not healthy.
It‚Äôs just less harmful than things like butter, lard, or hydrogenated oils. No matter how many virgins are attached to its label, at the end of the day, it‚Äôs still a refined, concentrated fat‚Äî99.9% oil, stripped of all the fiber and phytonutrients found in whole olives.
Worse still, it‚Äôs unsuited to Indian cooking.
We typically cook at high temperatures‚Äîthink of our tadkas and deep frying‚Äîand olive oil breaks down and oxidizes quickly at those temperatures, especially extra virgin olive oil. The fumes and byproducts can be harmful.
A better alternative for high-heat Indian cooking is mustard oil, which has a high smoke point and has traditionally been used in Indian kitchens. But again, only use it if you must. Eating whole mustard seeds in your food is far healthier than consuming mustard oil.
Better yet, explore oil-free cooking methods: steaming, dry roasting, saut√©ing in water or vegetable broth, and baking. You‚Äôll retain the flavors, improve your health, and save money.
In Summary:
When someone says ‚Äúthis food is healthy,‚Äù ask: Healthy compared to what?
Don‚Äôt fall for the trap of relative health claims.
‚Ä¢	Jaggery is healthier than sugar‚Äîbut it‚Äôs not healthy.
‚Ä¢	Red wine is better than whisky‚Äîbut it‚Äôs not good for you.
‚Ä¢	Olive oil is less harmful than butter‚Äîbut it‚Äôs still a processed, empty-calorie fat.
The only foods that truly promote health are whole, unrefined, plant-based foods‚Äîfruits, vegetables, legumes, whole grains, nuts, seeds, herbs, and spices.
And here‚Äôs the real rule of thumb:
If it grew on a plant, eat it.
If it was made in a plant, think twice.

‚Ä¢Doctors‚Äô Advice on Medications ‚Ä¢
If you are taking medication for a lifestyle disease, ask yourself: Why am I expected to take this for the rest of my life? Doctors often prescribe medications quickly because that‚Äôs what they are taught in medical school. Once you‚Äôre on lifelong medication, you become a lifelong patient‚Äîneeding refills, follow-ups, and continued medical supervision.
In India, many patients expect a prescription; if they leave a doctor‚Äôs clinic without one, they feel shortchanged. Deprescribing is rare. It isn‚Äôt in the interest of doctors or pharmaceutical companies to stop medications.
Here are some observations:
1. Symptom-Focused Approach
Most doctors focus on reducing symptoms to ‚Äúnormal‚Äù ranges. The underlying causes often remain unaddressed or are oversimplified‚Äîusually blamed on overeating or lack of exercise.
2. Prescription-Driven Practice
Doctors prescribe medication because that‚Äôs what is expected of them professionally and legally. It‚Äôs part of the standard treatment protocols they are trained to follow.
3. Lack of Nutrition Education
Doctors rarely discuss diet or lifestyle because they receive little to no training in nutrition. With limited time per patient, medication is often the quickest solution.
4. Medical Standards of Care
Doctors must follow standard care protocols to protect their licenses. In countries like the U.S., deviations can lead to malpractice lawsuits. Different specializations have different governing bodies. For example, both endocrinologists and general practitioners treat diabetes, but they may follow conflicting standards.
5. Governing Body Interests
Medical organizations often act in the interest of their members. Guidelines that lower diagnostic thresholds‚Äîmeaning more patients and more prescriptions‚Äîare adopted quickly. But when new evidence supports relaxing those thresholds, changes are slow.
A case in point:
In 1996, the fasting glucose cutoff for diagnosing diabetes was lowered from 140 to 126 mg/dL‚Äîquickly embraced by medical bodies. But in 2018, when guidelines were relaxed to an HbA1C of up to 8.0, it wasn‚Äôt widely adopted. The American Diabetes Association (ADA) recommends 7.0, while the American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists (AACE) recommends 6.5‚Äîleading to confusion.
This hesitation to reverse course is human nature. Once income increases, few willingly go back. A Hindi couplet from 400 years ago says:

Even when symptoms improve, doctors often discourage stopping medications. They believe the underlying disease is chronic and incurable, and improvements are solely due to ongoing medication.
Taking Charge of Your Health
As we explore various diseases in future blog posts, you will face these realities. Many people in my health group ask how to reduce or stop medications. It is inappropriate for me to provide individual medical advice. That‚Äôs a decision between you and your doctor.
However, I aim to empower you with knowledge so you can have a more informed conversation with your physician. Adopting a plant-based whole food (PBWF) diet, intermittent fasting, and a physically active lifestyle can lead to measurable improvements‚Äîand possibly reduced reliance on medication.
When & How to Reduce Medication
Once you consistently follow a PBWF diet, walk daily, and eat early dinners, you‚Äôll likely notice better sleep and increased energy. Track your blood pressure, blood sugar, and other markers at home. If they fall below clinical thresholds, discuss reducing your medications with your doctor.
Be aware: your doctor may not be familiar with the most recent guidelines (e.g., JNC-8 for blood pressure, ACP 2018 for diabetes). You may need to bring them up and explain your lifestyle changes. If your doctor is not open to adjusting medications, consider a second opinion.
Important: I am not a doctor and do not offer medical advice. Any change in medication must be done with your physician‚Äôs guidance.
A Case Example: Dr. McDougall‚Äôs Approach
Dr. John McDougall, in his 10-day live-in program in Santa Rosa, California, stopped all medications on day one‚Äîfor all participants. His reasoning: when patients switched to a PBWF diet, their markers improved rapidly, and continuing medication could cause harmful drops, especially in blood sugar for diabetic patients.
This illustrates why diabetic patients must reduce insulin and medications in coordination with their doctors when switching to a healthier lifestyle.
Guiding Principles
- Never stop medications without first changing your diet and lifestyle.
- Always prioritize sustainable lifestyle improvements over quick fixes.
- Regularly monitor your progress and keep your doctor informed.
- Respect that some doctors may not believe in stopping lifelong medications‚Äîseek a second opinion if needed.
- Understand that reducing medications safely depends on the severity of your condition and your consistency in following the new lifestyle.
Some people reduce medications by half every month, while others do so more gradually. If new guidelines suggest you were never a candidate for medication in the first place, your doctor may agree to stop it immediately.
For instance, current recommendations are:
- Blood Pressure: 140/90 for people under 60; 150/90 for those over 60
- Diabetes: HbA1C up to 8.0 is now considered acceptable in many cases
Final Note
Recent research shows that aggressively managing numbers (like glucose or BP) with medication can sometimes do more harm than good. This topic is discussed in my blog post, ‚ÄúBetter Safe Than Sorry‚Äù, where I debunk common medical myths.
The key takeaway: Start with food, not pharmaceuticals. As your health improves, let the numbers guide the conversation‚Äîwith your doctor. You deserve to know all your options.

‚Ä¢VITAMIN D SUPPLEMENTATION: A Deeper Look
I repeatedly try to emphasize a crucial point: our understanding of nutrition is still in its infancy. We‚Äôve only scratched the surface. When it comes to how food and nutrients interact with the body, there is far more we don‚Äôt know than we do. That‚Äôs why humility is essential when discussing nutrition‚Äîespecially with something as debated as vitamin D.
Dr. Robert Lustig of the University of California, San Francisco, shares a story from his first day at Cornell Medical School. During a welcome address, the Dean told incoming students: ‚ÄúHalf of what we‚Äôre going to teach you over the next four years is wrong. The problem is‚Äîwe don‚Äôt know which half.‚Äù
The ongoing debate over vitamin D in the medical community is a perfect example of this uncertainty, as you‚Äôll see in this blog.
The Vitamin D Debate
One of the most common and hotly debated questions I‚Äôm asked is:
Should we take vitamin D supplements?
Many people today are diagnosed as ‚Äúdeficient‚Äù in vitamin D. For years, the recommended healthy range has been 30‚Äì50 nanograms per milliliter (ng/ml). However, many experts‚Äîincluding my teacher, Dr. John McDougall‚Äîhad questioned this range, suggesting that 20‚Äì40 ng/ml may be more than sufficient.
But this raises a deeper question that often goes unaddressed:
Are people who are healthy because they have high vitamin D levels?
Or do they have high vitamin D levels because they‚Äôre healthy and spend more time outdoors?
In other words: is vitamin D causally linked to good health, or is it merely associated with it?
What COVID-19 Taught Us
During the COVID-19 pandemic, several studies found that people who experienced severe symptoms often had low vitamin D levels, while those with higher levels tended to do better. This seemed to support the idea that vitamin D was protective‚Äîbut again, the same question arose:
Were their outcomes better because of vitamin D?
Or were those people already healthier due to more sun exposure and better lifestyle habits, with high vitamin D levels being just one reflection of that?
The Emerging Science: Beyond Vitamin D
Recent research offers fascinating insights into the benefits of sunlight‚Äîmany of which go well beyond vitamin D production.
1.	Infrared Light and Melatonin Production
Sunlight contains a full spectrum of wavelengths from ultraviolet (UV) to infrared (IR). When our skin is exposed to IR light, it stimulates melatonin production within every cell of the body‚Äînot just in the brain.
This melatonin acts as a powerful antioxidant, helping to reduce oxidative stress and protect mitochondrial function.
2.	Ultraviolet Light and Vitamin D
Vitamin D is only synthesized when the skin is exposed to ultraviolet B (UVB) rays, which are shorter in wavelength. These rays are strongest around midday. However, during early mornings and late evenings, UVB rays are weaker due to the angle of the sun, while IR rays remain relatively strong.
3.	Sunlight and Blood Sugar Control
One study on patients with diabetes showed that post-meal blood sugar spikes were significantly lower when individuals were exposed to sunlight. This again points to broader benefits of sun exposure unrelated to vitamin D.
4.	Swedish Study on Sun Exposure and Mortality
In a remarkable 20-year study of 30,000 Swedish women, participants were grouped based on sun exposure: minimal, moderate, and high.
The findings were striking:
- Women with the highest sun exposure had the lowest mortality rates from cancer, cardiovascular, and non-cardiovascular diseases.
- Smokers in the high-sun group had the same mortality as non-smokers in the low-sun group.
In other words, lack of sun exposure was as dangerous as smoking.
5.	U.S. COVID Study and Geography
Data also showed that people living in southern U.S. states‚Äîwhere sun exposure is higher year-round‚Äîhad lower COVID-19 mortality rates than those in northern states.
Rethinking ‚ÄúDeficiency‚Äù
These recent research highlight an important nuance:
Time of day matters.
If someone gets regular morning or evening sun, they may benefit greatly from infrared exposure, which supports cellular health‚Äîbut their vitamin D levels may still be low, simply because UVB rays are weak at those times.
This means a person could have low vitamin D levels on paper yet still be in excellent health. On the flip side, someone supplementing to maintain high vitamin D levels might assume they are healthy, when in fact they are missing out on the broader benefits of real sunlight.
To Conclude:
Sunlight is more important than vitamin D. Even 15‚Äì20 minutes of sun exposure at any time of day supports mitochondrial function and reduces the risk of major metabolic diseases‚Äîincluding diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and even cancer.
For optimal vitamin D production, mid-morning (about 2 hours after sunrise) to mid-afternoon (2 hours before sunset) is the best time to get direct sun.
But don‚Äôt fall into the trap of thinking that a normal vitamin D level‚Äîachieved through supplements‚Äîmeans you‚Äôre fine. It‚Äôs not just about the number on the lab report. It‚Äôs about the quality of your sun exposure and its far-reaching effects on your overall health.

‚Ä¢Food Science, Nutrition, and Metabolic Health‚Ä¢
In the 1920s, research on celiac disease experienced by sailors on long voyages led to the discovery of vitamin C. At the time, the conclusion was not that the real issue was a lack of fresh fruits and vegetables, but rather a deficiency of a specific nutrient. This marked the beginning of what we now consider nutrition science.
Similarly, the development of antibiotics also in 1928 gave rise to modern health science, which often embraces the idea of ‚Äúa pill for every ill.‚Äù These approaches served us well for decades. However, a growing number of doctors and nutritionists are beginning to recognize that we may have made some critical errors in our understanding.
Dr. Colin Campbell, the number one nutritionist in the world, for example, has spoken out against the reductionist view of nutrition‚Äîwhere the focus is placed on individual nutrients rather than the complex interactions among them in whole plant foods. Just because a nutrient is isolated and supplemented doesn‚Äôt mean the body will absorb and utilize it effectively.
The emerging field of epigenetics has further challenged traditional views. It has shown us that bacteria are not necessarily our enemies‚Äîin fact, they are essential partners, producing many of the chemicals our bodies need. Every plant food has its own unique bacterial profile, which helps colonize our gut. Our immunity and overall health are deeply tied to the well-being of this internal ecosystem. Antibiotics, while sometimes necessary, can harm this microbial balance and have long-term consequences.
We seem to have come full circle, realizing that some of what we once thought was harmful may not be, and vice versa. Paradigms are shifting, and many of the lessons from the past century must be reconsidered.
New Insights
New insights continue to reshape our understanding. For example, the Nobel Prizes awarded in 2016, 2017, and 2018 highlighted groundbreaking discoveries in areas such as autophagy and circadian biology. These findings show that the absence of food‚Äîand the timing of food intake‚Äîcan be just as important as the food itself. This has profound implications for how we approach diet and lifestyle choices today.
Food Science, Nutrition & Metabolic Health
Food science, nutrition, and metabolic health are three distinct fields that are often misunderstood or used interchangeably. Here‚Äôs what each actually means:
* Food Science deals with what happens to food from the time it‚Äôs grown until it reaches your mouth‚Äîprocessing, storage, preservation, and preparation.
* Nutrition concerns what happens to food after it enters your mouth‚Äîhow it‚Äôs digested, absorbed, and transported to your cells.
* Metabolic Health focuses on what happens to food inside your cells‚Äîhow it‚Äôs used to produce energy and support cellular function.
The Real Problem: Metabolic Dysfunction
Many chronic diseases‚Äîsuch as type 2 diabetes, hypertension, cardiovascular disease, dyslipidemia, fatty liver, cancer, dementia, and PCOS‚Äîstem from metabolic dysfunction at the cellular level. These conditions account for nearly 75% of the entire U.S. healthcare budget. Despite this, our current medical approach largely focuses on symptom management rather than root-cause resolution. Here are some examples.
1.	Heart Disease:
We use statins to lower LDL cholesterol, but LDL is not the root problem‚Äîit‚Äôs a symptom or marker of an underlying issue. That‚Äôs why using statins for primary prevention doesn‚Äôt significantly extend lifespan: we‚Äôre not fixing the real problem.
2.	Hypertension:
We treat high blood pressure with medications, but we‚Äôre not addressing endothelial dysfunction‚Äîthe underlying issue that leads to kidney failure, heart failure, and more. Lowering blood pressure helps, but it‚Äôs a temporary patch, not a cure.
3.	High Blood Glucose:
We prescribe drugs to reduce blood sugar, but we‚Äôre not correcting insulin resistance or pancreatic beta-cell dysfunction, which are the actual causes. Again, lowering blood glucose isn‚Äôt bad, but it doesn‚Äôt fix the metabolic defects that led to it in the first place. We‚Äôre managing symptoms while ignoring the disease mechanism.
For the past seven decades, this symptom-based approach hasn‚Äôt solved the problem. It‚Äôs time to shift our mindset and focus on the root cause‚Äîmitochondrial dysfunction.
The Role of Mitochondria
Mitochondria are the powerhouses of the cell, generating ATP‚Äîthe chemical energy our bodies depend on. Without ATP, cells cannot function. When mitochondria fail, cells must shift to a less efficient energy system: fermentation instead of oxidation.
For example, cancer cells can survive without oxygen by relying heavily on glucose. Why? Because their mitochondria are damaged or entirely nonfunctional. This mitochondrial dysfunction is at the core of many metabolic diseases.
Rethinking Our Belief Systems
Much like religion, nutrition has long been treated as a matter of dogma. People change their religion usually because their current beliefs no longer serve them. The same is happening in nutrition.
People are questioning outdated ideas. For decades, we‚Äôve used a reductionist approach to food, focusing on isolated nutrients and calorie counting. But this has failed to improve public health. Experts like Dr. T. Colin Campbell and Dr. Robert Lustig have worked to challenge and dismantle these flawed beliefs. Dr. Campbell teaches that we should think of food as a whole, not just as a sum of its nutrient parts. Every food contains a unique ‚Äúsymphony‚Äù of nutrients that work together in ways we‚Äôre only beginning to understand.

‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ BREAKFAST OR NOT? ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Technically speaking, breakfast is simply the first meal of the day, no matter when you eat it. Whether it‚Äôs 7 a.m., noon, or 3 p.m.‚Äîwhenever you break your overnight fast, that is your ‚Äúbreak-fast.‚Äù
However, in common usage, breakfast is almost always associated with the early morning‚Äîa meal eaten shortly after waking up. This association is relatively modern in the sweep of human history.
A Brief History of ‚ÄúBreakfast‚Äù
The word breakfast appeared in written English during the 15th century, referring literally to the act of ‚Äúbreaking the fast‚Äù from the night before. In Old English, people used the word morgenmete, which simply meant ‚Äúmorning meal.‚Äù
Throughout much of human history, meals were shaped by necessity, not routine. People often ate one or two meals a day depending on their lifestyle, work, or availability of food. Regular morning meals were not always standard practice.
In fact, in many traditional cultures, people began their day with work or activity and did not eat immediately upon waking. Even today, in many parts of rural India or Africa, breakfast as we know it is minimal or delayed.
The Birth of the Modern ‚ÄúBreakfast‚Äù
The cultural and commercial rise of the modern breakfast owes much to one man: Dr. John Harvey Kellogg, a physician, health reformer, and Seventh-day Adventist who ran the Battle Creek Sanitarium in Michigan in the late 1800s.
Kellogg was obsessed with digestive health and bowel regularity. He was a strong proponent of bland, fiber-rich, meatless diets and believed that spicy or rich foods (as well as masturbation) led to poor health. He promoted enemas, hydrotherapy, and vegetarianism as tools for maintaining internal purity.
In his quest to develop a healthy, palatable food for his patients, he invented Corn Flakes, along with his brother, Will Keith Kellogg. Originally, the flakes were entirely plain and unsweetened‚Äîintended as a bland, wholesome food to calm the passions and nourish the gut.
Will Kellogg, however, saw commercial potential in this invention. He eventually added sugar to the flakes and began mass marketing them as a ready-to-eat breakfast cereal. The Kellogg Company was born, and with it began the commercialization of breakfast on a massive scale.
To help promote cereal, the idea that ‚Äúbreakfast is the most important meal of the day‚Äù was popularized. The phrase first appeared in Good Health magazine in 1917, written by Lenna F. Cooper, a nurse and dietitian trained under Dr. Kellogg. This slogan became a marketing hook‚Äîone that stuck, thanks to decades of advertising.
The Processed Food Industry Takes Over
Today, breakfast cereals are a multi-billion dollar industry. Aisles in grocery stores are lined with boxes claiming health benefits, energy boosts, or vitamin enrichment. Many of these cereals are loaded with sugar, preservatives, artificial flavors, and refined grains‚Äîa far cry from Kellogg‚Äôs original idea of health.
Despite these nutritional drawbacks, the belief that breakfast is essential‚Äîespecially cereal-based breakfast‚Äîremains deeply embedded in modern culture. But science is beginning to challenge this long-standing assumption.
Rethinking Breakfast in Light of Modern Science
Recent studies suggest that breakfast is not necessarily the most important meal of the day‚Äîespecially not for everyone.
In fact, for individuals suffering from chronic metabolic conditions‚Äîsuch as:
‚Ä¢	Type 2 diabetes
‚Ä¢	Hypertension
‚Ä¢	Obesity
‚Ä¢	Fatty liver
‚Ä¢	Metabolic syndrome
‚Äîskipping or delaying breakfast may actually be beneficial.
Why? Because the human body is not designed to be in a constant fed state. When we eat frequently and start early, we don‚Äôt allow the body time to repair, recycle, or switch metabolic gears.
Intermittent Fasting: The Metabolic Shift
The concept of intermittent fasting (IF) has gained scientific traction in recent years. One of the most common and effective patterns is the 16:8 method, where you fast for 16 hours and eat within an 8-hour window.
This method works with the body‚Äôs natural rhythm. Here‚Äôs how:
‚Ä¢	The liver stores about 500 calories worth of glucose (glycogen), which is used up in roughly 10‚Äì12 hours after your last meal.
‚Ä¢	Once glycogen is depleted, the body switches to burning fat for energy‚Äîentering a state called ketosis.
‚Ä¢	This fat-burning phase reduces visceral fat, liver fat, and intramyocellular lipids (fat stored in muscle).
‚Ä¢	It also triggers autophagy, a cellular clean-up process that helps prevent disease and promotes longevity. This process earned the 2016 Nobel Prize in Medicine.
So, by delaying or skipping breakfast, we allow the body to transition from glucose burning to fat burning, giving our organs a much-needed metabolic break.
But What If You Do Eat Breakfast?
If your lifestyle or health condition doesn‚Äôt require fasting‚Äîor if you‚Äôre still easing into the practice‚Äîyou can still make breakfast a nutritious and healing meal.
Here‚Äôs an ideal approach to break-fast when you‚Äôre ready to eat:
1.	Start with a Green Juice or Smoothie
Made from spinach, kale, green apples, amla, coriander, celery, cucumber, lemon, ginger etc. This provides chlorophyll, minerals, and enzymes.
2.	Follow with a Large Serving of Fruits
Fruits are rich in water, fiber, and natural sugars. They hydrate, cleanse the system, and provide quick energy without burdening digestion.
3.	Finish with a Whole Grain or Fermented Food
‚Ä¢	Oatmeal is excellent‚Äîrich in soluble fiber, it helps lower LDL cholesterol and keeps you full longer.
‚Ä¢	Idly with chutney (not sambhar) is another great option. Idly is fermented and steamed; chutney can be made oil-free. Avoid sambhar if it contains oil, as that adds unnecessary fat and can promote inflammation.
Final Thoughts
The blanket statement that ‚Äúbreakfast is the most important meal of the day‚Äù needs to be revisited in light of modern evidence. While breakfast might still be important for children, athletes, or those with special nutritional needs, it is not a universal rule‚Äîand certainly not a sacred one.
If you‚Äôre trying to reverse chronic illness, improve your metabolism, or lose excess fat, skipping or delaying breakfast and narrowing your eating window may be more effective than focusing on what you eat in the morning.
Let‚Äôs unlearn the myths handed down by food marketing, and instead make decisions based on biology, history, and personal health goals. Whether you eat breakfast or not‚Äîeat consciously, not conventionally.

The human body is remarkably efficient at converting excess calories into fat. This mechanism evolved as a survival strategy‚Äîstoring energy during times of abundance to sustain us during times of scarcity. Fat is found in all plant-based foods, and consuming just 10‚Äì15% of our daily calories from fat is more than sufficient for health.
There are three main types of fats:
- Saturated Fats: Primarily found in animal products. Among plant sources, coconut and palm kernel oil are notable examples.
- Monounsaturated Fats: Found in nuts, avocados, olives, and mustard seeds.
- Polyunsaturated Fats: This group includes essential fats like omega-3 (found in dark leafy greens, walnuts, flaxseeds, chia seeds) and omega-6 (found in corn, sunflower, safflower, and cottonseed oils).
Of all these fats, only two fatty acids are considered essential‚Äîmeaning the body cannot produce them on its own and they must be obtained through food. These are omega-3 and omega-6. Other fats are not considered essential.
Omega-3 fats exist in three forms:
- ALA (alpha-linolenic acid) ‚Äì Found in plant foods like flaxseeds, chia seeds, and walnuts.
- DHA (docosahexaenoic acid) and
- EPA (eicosapentaenoic acid) ‚Äì Found primarily in animal foods, especially fish.
The human body can convert ALA (from plant sources) into DHA and EPA, although this conversion rate is sometimes questioned. Based on certain studies, some experts suggest that the conversion may be inadequate, and therefore DHA/EPA supplements should be taken.
